children.name: to permanently leave the place where you live
leave
children.definition: to leave your home or the area where you live: rời đi
examples: This has been such a lovely home - I’ll be sorry to leave.
He left his hometown when he was 16, and he hasn’t been back there since.
Thousands of people have already left the capital in order to get away from the fighting.

children.name: move out
children.definition: topermanentlyleave your home, usually one yourentorsharewith sb else, taking all your possessions with you:chuyển đi, rời đi
examples: If the landlord raises the rent again, we’ll just have to move out.
Diana and I aren’t together any more. I’ve moved out.
move out of
Tom moved out of his apartment in Toronto last month.

children.name: leave home
children.definition: if ayoungperson leaves home, they leave their parents’ house because they think they are old enough to live on their own: bỏ nhà ra đi
examples: Gwen had left home at 18 to find a job in New York.
The house is getting too big for us now that both the children have left home.
Jane was sure that her decision to leave home and marry Joe was the right one.

children.name: run away
children.definition: if ayoungperson runs away, theysecretlyleave their parents’ home or the place where they are living because they are veryunhappythere: bỏ đi, bỏ nhà
examples: I ran away at the age of twelve, but my Dad came and found me at the bus station before I could leave town.
Malcolm and my sister are planning to run awaytogetherto get married.
run away from home
Thousands of children run away from home each year.
run away to
At the age of fifteen, Malcolm ran away to California.
runaway[C] những người bỏ nhà đi
This hostel helps runaways who don’t want to go back to their families.

children.name: vacate
children.definition: a word used especiallyin hotels,on notices etc meaning to leave the room or house you have been staying in, taking all your possessions with you:rời đi, trả phòng, trả ghế
examples: Guests are requested to vacate their rooms before 12 o'clock on the day of departure.

children.name: enter
children.definition: vào, đến
examples: Everyone entering the country must show a passport.
The barbed wire fences and mine fields are designed to stop people leaving or entering.
Congress is considering raising the number of skilled workers who may enter the country each year.

children.name: cross the border
children.definition: to enter a country from another country which is next to it, and is not separated from it by the sea:vượt biên giới
examples: Many people cross the border illegally in search of work.
cross the border into
Every day more and more desperate refugees were crossing the border into Kenya.

children.name: immigrate
children.definition: to enter another country in order to live there permanently:nhập cư
examples: immigrate to
Her father immigrated to America from China in 1947.
Born in Jamaica, Rigby had immigrated to England 30 years before.

children.name: immigration
children.definition: when people enter a country in order to live there permanently:sự nhập cư
examples: Most people in the UK believe that immigration has enriched the economy and national culture.
Immigration reached its peak in the 1950s.
Immigration officials stopped and arrested the man at JFK airport
immigrate to/into
Most immigration to New York City has been from the Caribbean, Europe, and Asia.
There are strict limits on immigration (intothe country).

children.name: to leave your house and go to live in another one
move
children.definition: to go to live in a new place:chuyển đi, rời đi
examples: ‘Do they still live on Reighton Road?’ ‘No, they’ve moved.’
move to/ from/ away/ out of/ with
Did you know that Karen’s moving to the US in August?
They moved from Burlington to Stowe about three months ago.
I hear Paula has moved inwithher boyfriend (= gone to live in his house) .
The couple next door movedaway(= went to live somewhere else) last year.
A lot of businesses are movingout ofLondon because it's too expensive.
move into
She moved into the new house as soon as the papers were signed.
move[C]C1sự chuyển đi
Some of our furniture got broken in the move while we were moving.
moving[ U ] going to a different place to live or work
I hate moving.

children.name: move house
children.definition: UK to leave your house and go to live in another one:chuyển nhà
examples: I’m not looking forward to moving house -- it’ll be a lot of work.
‘When are you moving house?’ ‘Next week, if everything goes to plan.’
The Chandlers are planning to move house in the next year or so.
Moving house can be extremely stressful.

children.name: to make sb leave the house where they live
kick out
children.definition: kick sb out/chucksboutUK  to force sb to leave the place where they live:đuổi ai đó đi
examples: Their landlord’s threatening to chuck them out.

children.name: evict
children.definition: to legally force sb to leave the house where they are living, especially because they should not be there or they have not paid their rent: đuổi
examples: If we are evicted, we’ll have nowhere to go.
They had been evicted for non-payment of rent.
Her mother, who has now been evicted from her home too, is staying with friends.
eviction[C or U]
He faces eviction because he has not paid his rent.

children.name: give sb notice
children.definition: to tell sb officially that they must leave the place they are renting by a particular date:đuổi đi
examples: How many weeks’ notice does your landlord have to give you?
give sb notice to leave/ quit
It came as a complete surprise to them when they were given notice to quit their premises within six days.

children.name: throw out
children.definition: throw sb out to force sb to leave the place where they live:đuổi ai đó đi
examples: Why were you thrown out of your apartment?
throw sb out on the streetmake sb leave their home immediately, even if they have nowhere else to go đuổi ai đó ra ngoài đường
She was thrown out on the street when her family discovered she was pregnant.

children.name: immigrant
children.definition: sb who enters another country in order to live there permanently:người nhập cư
examples: The new immigrants come mainly from Asia and Latin America
a large immigrantpopulation
immigrant from
Jae Min’s parents are immigrants from South Korea.
immigrant to
The winery was started by an Italian immigrant to California.
legal immigrant
The bill would have cut off government aid even to legal immigrants.
illegal immigrant(US alsoillegal alien) sb who goes to live or work in another country when they do not have the legal right to do this
Illegalimmigrants are sent back across the border if they are caught.

children.name: asylum-seeker
children.definition: sb who asks to be allowed to enter another country because they are not safe in their own country, especially because of their political beliefs or activities:người xin tị nạn
examples: Too often asylum-seekers are treated like criminals.
Officially recognized asylum-seekers cannot be deported.

children.name: to leave your country or the area where you live
emigrate
children.definition: to leave your owncountryto live permanently in another country, especially one which is far away:di cư
examples: Millie’s brother Dennis, and his wife Joan, decided to emigrate the following year.
emigrate to/ from
They later got married and emigrated to Australia in 1936.
My parents emigrated from Britain to New Zealand just before I was born.
Millions of Germans emigratedfromEuropetoAmerica in the nineteenth century.
emigration[C or U]
A major reason for emigration was the higher salaries that could be earned in some other countries.
emigrant[ C ] a person who emigrates

children.name: migrate
children.definition: If people migrate, they travel in large numbers to a new place to live temporarily: di cư, di trú
examples: How do birds know when to migrate, and how do they find their way back home?
migrate to/ into
Where there are areas of high unemployment, workers tend to migrate to other, wealthier parts of the country.
Mexican farm workers migrateintothe US each year to find work at harvest time.
migration[C or U]
Dr Baker has made detailed studies of the migration patterns of many birds.
migrant[C] sb who migrates: người di cư
The migrants travelled many miles before finally finding a suitable place to settle.
migrantworkers
The cities are full of migrants looking for work.
a migrant population
economic migrant[a person who leaves their home country to live in another country with better work or living conditions] công nhân xuất khẩu lao động đi nước ngoài

children.name: exodus
children.definition: the movement of a large number of people who leave their country, city etc because they do not want to live there any longer, or because it is not safe for them to stay: xuất hành
examples: The exodus of refugees continued throughout the autumn.
mass exoduswhen almost everyone leaves sự di tản số đông
The island is facing a mass exodus of its young people.
There has been amassexodus of workersfromthe villages to the towns.

children.name: to start to live in a place
settle
children.definition: to start to live permanently in a country or city, after you have lived in several different places: định cư
examples: settle in
We lived in Thailand, then Singapore, and finally settled in Hong Kong.
The family settled in a small Nevada town where they opened a store.
After they got married, they settledinBrighton.

children.name: set up house U
children.definition: set up house to start to live in your own home for the first time, for example after getting married or leaving your parents’ home:
examples: They first set up house together in Atlanta and moved to Miami three years later.
He rarely left the Brooklyn apartment where he had set up house.
set up house with
Her parents were very upset when she set up house with her boyfriend.

children.name: take up residence
children.definition: formal to start to live in a country, city, or a building, especially in order to start working at a job:
examples: take up residence in
He left the country in December to take up residence in Panama.
take up residence at
In 1953 Diem took up residence at a monastery in Belgium.

children.name: political asylum
children.definition: the protection given by a government to foreign people who have left their own country because they disagree with their own government : quyền tị nạn chính trị
examples: The number of peopleseekingpolitical asylum in Britain has risen dramatically.

children.name: refugee camp
children.definition: a place where people who have escaped their own country can live, usually in bad conditions and only expecting to stay for a limited time : trại tị nạn

children.name: transit camp
children.definition: a place where refugees stay in tents or other temporary structures when they have nowhere to live permanently : trại tị nạn

children.name: immigration
children.definition: nounkiểm soát nhập cảnh
examples: the process of examining yourpassportand other documents to make certain that you can be allowed to enter the country, or the place where this is done
_After you've been through immigration(control), you can go and get your luggage.
_immigration policy
_immigration officers

children.name: brain drain
children.definition: noun sự chảy máu chất xám
examples: when large numbers of educated and very skilled people leave their own country to live and work in another one where pay and conditions are better
_Britain has suffered a huge brain drain in recent years.

children.name: move on
children.definition: phrasal verbNEW PLACE
examples: to leave the place where you are staying and go somewhere else
_I've been inParislong enough - it's time to move on.

children.name: resettle
children.definition: verbtái định cư; đưa ngườiđến sống
examples: to (be helped or forced to) move to another place to live
_His family originally came fromIreland, but resettledintheUSin the 19th century.
_TheUSgovernment forcibly resettled the Native Americansinreservations.
resettlementnoun[ U ]
_the resettlement of refugees
